text:
hi,

This is not a bug, just a suggestion.

Sometimes it is necessary to back trace session data to the originating client.
It would be really useful if StandardSession has IP address of the client as a
property. 

Thanks in advance,
Vlad
creator: vlad@jstripe.com

text:
But an ISP could use a cluster of transparent proxies that mask the real source
IP and distribute traffic from one user across many IPs. eg:
http://webmaster.info.aol.com/proxyinfo.html
creator: sandymac@apache.org

text:
I'd say AOL is rather an exception then rule. The session could store the
"latest" IP address, which is going to be at least something in AOLs case. Or
even better still, it can store the list of IP addresses accessed the session. 

Monitoring for sessions with multiple IP addresses could flag possible
clustering/load-balancing or security ussues.

Any thoughts?
creator: vlad@jstripe.com

text:
I agree with Sandy:  AOL is the rule, not the exception.  In general, the IP 
address of the proxy will change with any large organization.

In any case, it is possible to implement this yourself with a simple Filter.  
Which means that there really isn't any reason to promote feature-bloat in the 
Tomcat core.
creator: william.barker@wilshire.com
vlad@jstripe.com
text:
I cannot dispute anything you've mentioned. However, I run an open-source
project www.tomcatprobe.org and I've been asked on many occasions if the app can
display IP address of a session, which I would agree with if it was possible.
Unfortunately even the simplest Filter is not an option  as the app displays
sessions that belong to other applications. So if Tomcat core is not going to
support the feature it is the end of the road for me.

So I'm just hoping that you may reconsider.

creator: shankarunni@netscape.net
text:
(In reply to comment #1)
> But an ISP could use a cluster of transparent proxies that mask the real source
> IP and distribute traffic from one user across many IPs. eg:
> http://webmaster.info.aol.com/proxyinfo.html

But even with this scheme, there are usually headers that identify the
"original" IP address (inserted by the load-balancer or proxy). But tracing
through them is a royal pain (and heuristic at best).
